pageContent:
How are honey bees built? 
Anatomy and Physiology I 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
• 
Sketch a 
honey bee
, locate its basic body parts, and know their function 
• 
Explain why the exoskeleton is remarkable, yet recognize some of the 
drawbacks of having an external skeleton 
• 
Contrast key sensory organs (sight, smell, taste, and touch) 
• 
Compare bee vision and human vision 
• 
Explain how 
honey bees 
walk, and how they fly

How are honey bees built? 
Anatomy and Physiology I 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
• 
Sketch a 
honey bee
, locate its basic body parts, and know their function 
• 
Explain why the exoskeleton is remarkable, yet recognize some of the 
drawbacks of having an external skeleton 
• 
Contrast key sensory organs (sight, smell, taste, and touch) 
• 
Compare bee vision and human vision 
• 
Explain how 
honey bees 
walk, and how they fly

wings and six legs are attached to 
thorax
Drawing incorrectly shows hind legs 
attached to abdomen

General external morphology 
*
Three body regions: 
• 
Head 
• 
Thorax 
with 3 
pairs of legs and 
2 pairs of wings 
• 
Abdomen 
*
All made of 
segments, 
sometimes fused 
*Joint appendages 
*Soft structures 
encased in 
exoskeleton

outside the bee 
The exoskeleton 
(AKA cuticle) 
o
 
Epicuticle: has 
waterproof wax layer 
o
 
Procuticle: contains 
microfibers of chitin 
and proteins 
o
 
Epidermis
-
secretory 
tissue that produces 
the overlying layers 
o
 
Basement 
membrane:separate 
body cavity from 
cuticle 
Inside the bee 
–
body cavity 
organs are floating around in a liquid called hemolymph

The honey bee exoskeleton is multilayered yet each of 
these layers is rotated by WAYYYY 
less 
than 90 degrees 
to one another

About 20 layers of 
chitin+protein  constitute 
one pitch of the helical arrangement

Do not think about the cuticle as a UNIFORM body armor: some 
areas in the ABDOMEN are thin, and allow freedom of 
movement as well as exchanges between the body cavity and 
the outside world 
sclerite 
sclerite 
Thin membrane 
between two sclerites 
on the abdomen 
Secretions from 
Glands can ooze 
From the exoskeleton

Varroa mites lodged BETWEEN 
Honey bee worker 
sclerites where they pierce the thin 
exposing 
Nasonov's gland 
(white 
– 
at 
membrane between sclerites and feed 
tip of abdomen) releasing pheromone

The honey bee  exoskeleton is covered 
in ~ 3 million “hairs” (=seta, setae) 
hair even on top of eyes
Hair is adaptation to lifestyle- 
allows them to collect pollen
with front legs- brushing 
herself, her head, her 
mouthpart, proboscis - and 
transferring pollen to middle 
leg, and then eventually to 
back leg (in span of a few 
min)
What makes the hairs of 
honey bees particularly 
good at carrying pollen 
grains?
Answer:
They are branched 
AND 
They are slightly positive 
charged while pollen is 
slightly negatively charged

• 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bQZQH93H1KY&list=PPSV&ab 
_channel=GeorgiaTech 
(0:11 to 0:56)

Courtesy of 
Dr. Megan Asche (
honey bee
, 
Apis 
mellifera
) 
Spikiness of pollen grain is 
an adaptation by plants to 
help with transportation 
from animals

Honey bees are 
encased in a hard, and 
semi rigid body armor except for the 
articulations at the joints, and the 
membranous areas between sclerites. So 
how do they monitor changes in their 
environment? Temperature? Humidity? 
Pressure? How do they perceive odors, and 
chemicals in their environment?

Sensilla are tiny organs on the outer surface 
of the exoskeleton that are connected to sensory neurons. 
One tiny area of the exoskeleton can have FIVE TYPES of sensilla: 
trichoid
-
A (t), 
basiconic 
(b), ampullaceal (a), coeloconic (co), AND 
coelocapitular 
(ca) sensilla! 
Please do not remember any of those names 
•

Cuticle 
Cap 
Dendrite 
Sensory Neuron 
Campaniform Sensilla 
• 
Campaniform Sensilla  are 
cuticular caps in the 
exoskeleton innervated by a 
single nerve 
• 
Responds to compression of 
the exoskeleton, such as 
when it flexes during 
movement" 
• 
Sensory feedback from 
campaniform sensilla is 
integrated in the control of 
posture and locomotion. 
Axon 
cuticular cap - respond to compression of exoskeleton, 
useful to get info for locomotion and posture

Trichoid Sensilla 
(Means “hair
-
like”) 
•
“
Touch
”
 
sensilla 
•
Bending/Deflection
 of hair 
fires neuron 
•
Neuron 
firing rate related 
to extent of deflection

cuticle 
Taste sensilla and 
Olfactory sensilla 
1) 
Chemicals* enter 
pore/pores 
2) 
Chemicals bind to 
receptors on dendrites 
then change sensory 
neuron firing rate 
*chemicals can be airborne (volatiles, ex: plant 
odors, female scent) or detected by contact 
(ex: sugar on plant) 
Have holes throughout the peg 
involved in detecting of 
sugar/bitter compounds in 
nectar of flowers
Has only one pore at top of 
peg

A summary of the 
many functions 
of a honey 
b
ee’s cuticle 
Wax layer
Due to pigments or 
microstructure of 
skeleton deflects 
light in certain 
ways to produce 
certain color
Any potential drawbacks of having an exoskeleton:
•
limits growth 
•
Have to shed skin to grow, vulnerable; but honey bees safe inside hive
•
heals slower, have to wait for next mold

Human 
Exoskeletons? 
Tom Cruise in “The edge 
of tomorrow”

Head
 
• 
Compound 
Eyes 
• 
Three Ocell
i 
• 
Antennae 
• 
Mandibles 
• 
Proboscis

Ocellus
/Ocelli
 
bee head 
showing 3 ocelli 
(
FYI: this is NOT a honey 
bee because honey 
bees have too many hairs in that area and 
• 
Functions: 
Is it day or night?  Am I in the 
thus one can hardly see the ocelli!
) 
light or in the dark?  How bright is it? Is 
an object moving? How fast? 
Always 3!
responsible for detection of light/ 
shadows/variations of light

Compound Eye 
Elements of the 
insect compound 
eye. The basic 
unit is an 
ommatidium
. 
Responsible for image formation
Hairs are lodged in between ommatidia
less than 7,000 ommatidia

How do honey bees see the world 
Human 
eye 
honey bee 
e
ye 
Poor spatial resolution and visual acuity 
good enough 
despite this blurry 
image since they 
aren’t predators 
and don’t need 
better vision to 
catch prey

DOI:
Do honey bees see shapes? 
https
://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2006.01.002
 
Yes, discovered in 1920s
see difference between diamonds and 
circles
Differences in between colors

visualacuityvariesacross
theeye
Do honey bees see colors? 
Bee color vision is trichromatic 
(like humans), based on three 
photoreceptor types (S, M, L), 
which peak in the UV, blue, and 
green region of the spectrum. 
Human 
Bee 
vision 
vision 
Bees do not see red or orange, but can see past 
violet (Ultraviolet or UV light)
flowers emit UV light 
that attracts bees
If bees can’t see red 
wavelength, then how 
are red flowers 
pollinated?
can use other senses, 
like olfaction
Could still see 
contrast in flower
Could attract other 
types of pollinators 
ex:birds
some bees see a little 
bit in red wavelength
Vast majority of bees are on purple, blue, and yellow flowers

visualacuityvariesacross
theeye
Also, they can see polarized light (and you 
can’t!
) 
Polarized light 
-- Light reflected from atmospheric molecules produces 
a polarization pattern in the sky 
sun
 
viewer
 
Bees can navigate based on polarized light 
always knows where the sun is, even when its cloudy, and it’s important because otherwise they get lost

Summary of the Visual functions 
of compound eyes: 
• 
Acuity 
– 
Forming patterns and 
images 
• 
Depth 
– 
How far away is something? 
Distance to an object? 
• 
Color 
– 
What wavelength of light is 
being emitted? 
• 
Polarization 
– 
What is the angle of 
the light waves reflected off the sky? 
Where is the sun on a cloudy day?
Antennae

Mouthparts 
o
 
Mandibles 
used for 
cutting, shaping, 
manipulating wax 
o
 
Proboscis 
includes 
Glossa 
(tongue) 
covered by hairs that 
stick to nectar or 
water 
Proboscis is folded under 
the head and extended 
when in use

Used for: 
Ingestion of liquid (nectar, honey, water). 
Mouth
-
to

mouth exchange of fluids 
They kind of lap like cats 
(trophallaxis)

musculature to

and flying

foreleg

leg

How do

walk?
•
Honeybees walk with all six legs

Alternating tripod

Wings
Forewing and hindwing
Hooked together for flight
By 
hooks
 
called 
hamuli

How do 
bees
 
fly?
Definitely NOT like birds!

Two sets of indirect 
flight muscles: DLM 
and DVM
Indirect flight 
muscles don’t attach 
to the wings.
They deform the 
thorax, causing wings 
to flap  (go up or 
down)
DLM
DVM
DVM
ventral
Thorax  
-
  
cross section
Indirect flight muscles
PWP
 
(fulcrum)
dorsal
 
https://www.youtube.com/w
atch?v=yRE2rMIXvyU

When 
DVM muscles 
contract, 
top of thorax is pulled down => wings go up
When 
DLM muscles 
contract, 
thorax is squeezed front
-
to
-
back, top pops up
 
 
 
 
 
     
=> wings go down
PWP
(fulcrum)
PWP
(fulcrum)

Direct flight muscles control direction
L
e
g
•
Two sets of direct flight 
muscles
•
They pull on small bits
  
of cuticle (sclerites) at     
the wing base
•
tilts the front edge of the 
wing down or  tilts the 
back edge of the wing 
down
